div.head: Explanatory Power as a Substitute for Statistical Reasoning
div.p: We must often assess causal claims on the fly, with limited computational resources and statistical evidence. In these situations, people use several cues to assess whether a causal relationship exists, including mechanism knowledge (e.g., Johnson & Ahn, 2017), temporal information (e.g., Bramley et al., 2018), and event structure (e.g., . Less is known, however, about how causal strength is estimated when covariation information is unavailable-i.e., given that a causal relationship exists, how powerful is that relationship between cause and effect? Here, we examine one potential cue people might use to estimate causal strength in statistically impoverished settings-explanatory power.
Normative models of causal strength typically define causal strength in terms of statistical contingency (Perales & Shanks, 2007), making covariation evidence indispensable.

For example, one account models causal strength as the magnitude of difference the cause makes to the probability of the effect (Allan, 1980). Determining these probabilities requires multiple observations to calculate the covariation between cause and effect.

Yet, we have intuitions about causal strength in one-shot cases where we observe a cause and effect occur just one time, and thus lack any statistical evidence. When a new legal statute has an unintended social consequence, when an earnings report affects a company's business plan, or when ingesting an unfamiliar drink causes a funny tingling, we have a sense of how powerful these causes are in producing the effects, even though we may lack statistical data entirely. Where do these intuitions come from?

One possible source is a cause's explanatory power. People seem to use a variety of explanatory virtues (Lipton, 2004) or heuristics (Johnson et al., 2019) to judge an explanation's quality, such as simplicity, scope, and depth (e.g., Johnson et al., 2019;Khemlani et al., 2011;Lombrozo, 2012Lombrozo, , 2016. Critically, these heuristics often are defined in one-shot cases, so beliefs about explanatory power can often be formed in the absence of statistical evidence. For instance, people usually prefer simpler over more complex causal explanations (Lombrozo, 2007;cf. Zemla et al., 2017); perhaps, then, people would believe that a simpler cause would be a more potent cause than a more complex one.

Though the assumption that more "virtuous" explanations are stronger causes could sometimes lead to erroneous inferences, it may often be adaptive since explanatory power and causal strength are usually correlated (Strevens, 2008). For instance, if a new law inadvertently incentivizes people to drive faster, then the law will be seen as a good explanation for driving speed to the extent that the law made a large causal difference to driving speed. People might capitalize on this relationship between causal strength and explanatory power in the reverse direction, using their own explanatory judgments to predict causal strength. If explanatory power can sometimes be more easily assessed than causal strength, then this may be an effective strategy for inferring causal strength, especially in one-shot cases.

Four studies examine this case. First, Study 1 tests whether explanatory power and causal strength judgments are indeed highly correlated-a necessary condition for the heuristic value of explanatory power. Second, Studies 2 and 3 ruled out alternative explanations for this relationship, experimentally manipulating independent cues to explanatory power and looking for downstream effects on causal strength judgments. Finally, Study 4 looked for causal signatures of explanatory thinking in a putatively non-causal domain-mathematical explanation.

div.head: Study 1
div.p: Historical events may be the prototypical example of a singular causal situation where statistical data is typically unavailable due to the unique kaleidoscope of circumstances. This lack of statistical data in the case of many pivotal-and therefore unique-historical events has fueled countless debates among professional historians, such as the role of individual agency versus societal or economic factors in driving particular historical events (Callinicos, 1987). In Study 1, we draw on the unique nature of historical events as an initial test of the relationship between explanatory power and causal strength in a naturalistic setting.

div.head: Methods
div.p: Participants in all studies were recruited from Amazon Mechanical Turk and provided informed consent. We recruited two groups of participants (N=40 for each of Studies 1A and 1B); 16 participants were excluded for incorrectly answering more than 30% of the check questions. Statistical power was high despite the relatively small sample, since analyses were conducted at the item level and all participants completed all 54 items (i.e., the data comprise 3,456 data points after exclusions).

div.head: Participants read about 54 pairs of real historical events. For example:
div.p: A. The Black Plague rampaged through Europe from 1347 to 1351. B. The price of labor in Europe skyrocketed.

For a complete list of event pairs, see Appendix S1 in the Supplementary Materials. For each pair, participants in Study 1A were asked "To what extent do you think that A is a satisfying explanation for why B happened?" from 0 ("Not at all satisfying") to 10 ("Very satisfying").
Study 1B was identical, except they were told that "A happened, and this caused B to happen" and asked "How strong do you think this causal relationship is between A and B?"

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: Analyses were conducted at the item level, averaging over participants and using the 54 items as the units of analysis. The correlation between explanatory power judgments (Study 1A) and causal strength judgments (Study 1B) was of a magnitude not commonly seen in social science research, r(52)=.961, p<.001 (Figure 1). For practical purposes, the dependent variables in Studies 1A and 1B were treated by participants as the same question. This result, taken alone, would be utterly unconvincing evidence for our thesis that explanatory power is a cue to causal strength because reverse causation explanations are eminently plausible: If people have beliefs about the strength of a causal relationship, it would be surprising if those beliefs did not inform their explanatory intuitions. Yet we take this exceptionally strong correlation as an important starting point for three reasons. First, the (Study 1A) correlation is a precondition for the usefulness of explanatory power as a heuristic for causal strength, as this correlation demonstrates that the cue is often valid. Second, the magnitude of this correlation strikes us as implausibly large if it reflected only the influence of causal strength on explanatory power because many other factors are known to influence explanatory judgments (Lombrozo, 2016). Third, the ecological validity of Study 1 is a useful supplement to our more artificial and controlled experiments to follow. White circles indicate observed predictions (known to be true) and gray circles indicate latent predictions (not known to be true or false).

div.head: Study 2
div.p: The quality of an explanation depends not only on its relationship with what it is explaining, but also the other predictions it makes-its scope. For example, Ferraro's Disorder (C) might have three symptoms-hair loss (E1), weight gain (E2), and night terrors (E3). When diagnosing the cause of Randy's hair loss (E1), we benefit from knowing about E2 and E3 (C's scope) in assessing whether Ferraro's Disorder is the best explanation ( Figure 2B). Scope can be broken into two parts-its observed predictions or manifest scope (Read & Marcus-Newhall, 1993), and its potential-yet-unverified explanations or latent scope (Khemlani et al., 2011). For example, if we do not know whether or not Randy had night terrors (E3), then E3 is part of C's latent scope ( Figure 2C). People typically prefer explanations that make many verified predictions (wide manifest scope; Johnston et al., 2017;Read & Marcus-Newhall, 1993) and few unknown predictions (narrow latent scope; Johnson et al., 2016;Khemlani et al., 2011).

Study 2 used these phenomena to manipulate explanatory power, looking for downstream effects on causal strength. Participants read vignettes depicting a causal relationship, where we varied features of the explanatory structure, such that some explanations were "good" and others were "bad." In Study 2A, we contrasted explanations with wider manifest scope (the Good condition; Figure 2A) to explanations with narrower manifest scope (the Bad-Manifest condition; Figure 2B). For example, a Good item read: That is, Ferraro's Disorder (C) has three effects in its scope-hair loss (E1), weight gain (E2), and night terrors (E3), of which all three were observed. In contrast, a Bad-Manifest item read:

When someone has Ferraro's Disorder, they lose hair. Three months ago, Randy developed Ferraro's Disorder. Because he has Ferraro's Disorder, Randy lost hair. We also know that Randy gained weight and had frequent night terrors, but we don't know why.
Here, Randy still has the same three symptoms, but two are unexplained. We expected that

Ferraro's Disorder would be seen as a more powerful explanation for Randy's hair loss when it explained all of Randy's symptoms (in the Good condition), rather than just one (in the Bad-Manifest condition).

In Study 2B, we contrasted the same Good explanations ( Figure 2B) with Bad-Latent explanations ( Figure 2C) that predicted the same effects as the Good explanations, but where some of the predicted effects were latent. This version read:

When someone has Ferraro's Disorder, they lose hair, gain weight, and have frequent night terrors. Three months ago, Randy developed Ferraro's Disorder. Because he has Ferraro's Disorder, Randy lost hair. We don't know if he gained weight or had frequent night terrors.

In this version, Ferraro's Disorder accounts for three potential observations, with E1 observed (in the manifest scope) and E2 and E3 unknown (in the latent scope). We expected Ferraro's Disorder to be seen as a more powerful explanation of Randy's hair loss when it made predictions that were manifest rather than latent.

In all three versions, Ferraro's Disorder is said to have caused Randy's hair loss, but the extent to which Ferraro's Disorder is judged as a strong cause should differ across conditions. In contrast, if only the reverse were true-that causal strength merely influences explanatory power-then these manipulations should have no effect on causal judgments.

div.head: Methods
div.p: We recruited 100 participants each for Studies 2A and 2B; 1 participant was excluded for incorrectly answering more than 33% of the check questions.

Items were causal explanations drawn from eight categories covering a variety of topics (e.g., medicine, sports, chemistry). Each category contained two items, which were conceptually similar but differed in content (e.g., the two medical items described different fictitious diseases with distinct symptoms). Each participant thus completed a total of 16 items. In Study 2A, participants saw the Good version of one item from each category and the Bad-Manifest version of the other item from each category, in a counterbalanced manner (see above for example wordings). In Study 2B, participants saw the Good version of one item from each category and the Bad-Latent version of the other item. In both studies, each Good item was always presented adjacent to a Bad item from a different category, forming eight pairs; the order within each pair was randomized, as was the order of the pairs.

For each of the 16 items, participants first read the explanation (as worded above for each condition, with the effects color-coded to make the paragraphs easier to parse). Participants then answered a causal structure question (e.g., "Do you think that Randy having Ferraro's Disorder caused him to lose hair?") formatted as a yes/no forced-choice, to ensure that participants acknowledged the existence of a causal relationship. On the next screen, they rated causal strength ("How strong do you think this relationship is between Randy having Ferraro's Disorder and Randy losing hair?") on a scale from 1 ("Extremely Weak") to 9 ("Extremely Strong"), with the passage from the previous page at the bottom of the screen as a reminder.

They were asked to make this strength rating regardless of their response to the structure question, because we wanted to discourage participants from adopting the strategy of answering "no" to the initial question in an effort to shorten the task.

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: Both manipulations of explanatory structure influenced causal strength judgments, and this effect was larger in Study 2B than in Study 2A ( Figure 3). For each participant, we averaged across the items for which that participant answered "yes" to the initial causal structure question ("Do you think that [C] caused [E1]?"). These strength ratings were modestly higher for the We predicted these results because we anticipated that explanatory scope-which is known to independently affect perceived explanatory quality-would be used as a cue to causal

strength. An alternative interpretation is that participants' answers to the strength questions may not have reflected their beliefs about causal strength at all, but instead their beliefs about causal structure-whether a causal relationship exists rather than its strength (Griffiths & Tenenbaum, 2005). However, we took several measures to guard against this possibility. Critically, we sought to eliminate possible uncertainty over the causal structure by stating explicitly that the cause occurred (e.g., "Three months ago, Randy developed Ferraro's disorder") and that it caused the effect in the token case (e.g., "Because he has Ferraro's disorder, Randy lost hair"). We also added a separate structure question prior to the strength question ("Do you think that Randy having Ferraro's disorder caused him to lose hair?"), creating pragmatic pressure to interpret strength and structure as distinct queries.

Separating out structure and strength questions also allowed us to include only causal strength ratings among those who agreed that the causal relationship occurred. div.head: Study 4
div.p: So far, we have seen that in causal scenarios, explanatory power cues causal strength.
Might an analogous effect extend even to a seemingly non-causal domain? In Study 4, we studied the downstream effects of mathematical explanation on counterfactual judgments.
Although '4-2=2' and '2+2=4' are mathematically equivalent, they are not psychologically equivalent. Addition is seen as a more primitive operation than subtraction;

therefore, people believe that "4-2=2 because 2+2=4" is a better explanation than "2+2=4 because 4-2=2" since the former grounds a less basic in a more basic operation rather than the converse (Johnson, Johnston, Koven, & Keil, 2015). Although we doubt that people would view addition facts as "causing" subtraction facts, we speculated that explanatory power might imbue causal properties-specifically, counterfactual inferences-into mathematics.

Causal and counterfactual judgments are tightly linked (Pearl, 2000): To a first approximation, "C caused E" typically entails that "If C had not happened, E would not have happened" (with exceptions; Paul & Hall, 2013). In contrast, the converse counterfactual "If E had not happened, C would not have happened" feels unnatural because it violates the usual cause-to-effect order of reasoning. Thus, causes appear to be more stable to counterfactual alterations compared to effects. We hypothesized that, similarly, the link between explanatory power and causal strength would lead more explanatorily primitive mathematical operations (e.g., addition) to be more stable to counterfactual alterations compared to less primitive operations (subtraction). That is, it should be more difficult to imagine a world where the facts of addition are different, compared to a world where the facts of subtraction differ.

div.head: Method
div.p: We recruited 100 participants from Amazon Mechanical Turk; 26 participants were excluded for incorrectly answering more than 30% of the check questions, but including these participants does not alter the conclusions.

div.head: Participants were instructed:
div.p: There was once a sorcerer named Prospero. Prospero waved his wand, and some of the facts of mathematics changed. Unfortunately, we aren't sure which facts changed and which remained the same. On the following pages, you will read about some mathematical facts that remained true and others that became false. Your task will be to help determine which mathematical facts are true even after Prospero waved his wand, and which became false.

They then made a series of choices on Likert scales. For each choice, participants were told that "After Prospero waved his wand, one of the following statements became false and the other remained true. Which one do you think is still true?" For five items, one statement was formulated in terms of addition (e.g., "3+1=4") and the other in terms of subtraction ("4-1=3");

for five items, one was multiplication ("2x3=6") and the other division ("6/2=3"); and for five items, one was exponentiation ("4^2=16") and the other rooting ("sqrt(16)=4"). In all cases, choices were made on a scale from -5 to 5, with each scale extreme marked with one of the statements (randomized by item). For analyses, scores were coded such that negative numbers correspond to the more basic operation (addition, multiplication, exponentiation). Due to a typo, we excluded one multiplication/division item from analyses, but including it does not alter the conclusions.
After the 15 items of the main task (but without a clear demarcation from the participants' perspective), a further 6 items were presented wherein one statement was true (e.g.,

("32/4 = 8") and the other false ("4x8=40"). These were used as check questions. Numeracy (Lipkus et al., 2001) was then measured for exploratory purposes; however, we did not analyze numeracy and do not discuss it further.

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: Participants preferred to retain the statement described in terms of the more 'basic' These results accord with the notion that differences in explanatory power translate into resistance to counterfactual alteration. This provides suggestive evidence that the links between explanatory power and causal strength we saw in Studies 1-3 may extend even to putatively noncausal domains such as mathematics. Future research might assess whether the imposition of mental causal models on mathematics has implications for mathematics instruction.

div.head: General Discussion
div.p: Even though life often fails to lay out statistical information in a digestible way, we are nonetheless able to infer causal strength from individual cases. To see whether this ability might in part draw on our explanatory capacities, we used three different methods to demonstrate the link between explanatory power and causal strength judgments. Study 1 found that, within a sample of naturalistic historical events, the two judgments were almost perfectly correlated.

Studies 2 and 3 used an experimental approach to show that manipulating a cause's perceived explanatory power, even when there is no doubt about causal structure, affects the perceived strength of that cause. Study 4 revealed signatures of explanatory power on counterfactual judgments even in the (seemingly) non-causal domain of mathematics.

These results add to previous research documenting ways that prior knowledge influences causal judgments. For example, covariation information has a stronger effect on causal judgments when the causal candidate is believable than when it is unbelievable (Fugelsang & Thompson, 2000) and both laypeople and working scientists discount data that is inconsistent with their hypotheses (Fugelsang, Stein, Green, & Dunbar, 2004).

The present results differ from these prior findings, however, in demonstrating that even in the absence of any data, beliefs about explanatory power can influence judgments of causal strength. Instead, these findings may be more closely related to analogical mappings from one causal token to another (Holyoak, Lee, & Lu, 2010), where covariation information is not used at all. The tight coupling between causal and explanatory strength seems to license a heuristic wherein one can be used as a proxy for the other in any token case, without necessarily referring to the statistics of the broader reference class. This may explain in part why people often prefer explanatory information over statistical information when evaluating causal tokens (e.g., "Jim's smoking caused him to get lung cancer"), but prefer statistical information when evaluating causal types ("A person's smoking causes them to get lung cancer"; Johnson & Keil, 2016).

An open question for future research is whether a similar explanatory heuristic could be at play in causal structure inference as well. The present studies were not designed with this question in mind (we specified that causal relationships existed in all cases), but participants in Study 2 were indeed somewhat more likely to reject the structure claim (e.g., "Randy having Ferraro's disorder caused him to lose hair") when explanatory quality was lower. Future studies might test this possibility by manipulating explanatory virtues that do not normatively license different inferences in structurally ambiguous cases.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: We must often infer both the shapes and sizes of causal relationships without contingency information at our disposal, and in such cases we must rely on prior knowledge and cues from the environment to make these inferences. The present results show that the explanatory power of a causal relationship is one guide we use to make these strength inferences. This finding underscores the importance of research on explanatory preferences by documenting downstream consequences of explanatory reasoning for causal inference. Just as the explanatory structures in our minds mirror causal structure in the world, so do our causal perceptions mirror our explanatory intuitions. More thorough understanding of both sides of this feedback loop will be needed to ground this circle between mind and environment.

Across all 48 combinations of item and version, the correlation between explanatory power and causal strength was highly robust, r(46)=.65, p<.001. Looking just within each version of each item, this correlation was significant within the Bad-Manifest items, r(14)=.70, p=.002, and positive but non-significant within the Good items, r(14)=.19, p=.48, r(14)=.42, p=.11. These positive correlations help to buttress the case that the findings of Study 2 were indeed driven by explanatory power.
